WRITING.TITLE: THE THREESOME ANTHONY BOURDAIN WILL NEVER HAVE (weird lesbian vegan fanfic)
WRITING.TEXT: My first serious girlfriend idolised Anthony Bourdain. She read her uncle #8217;s copy of Kitchen Confidential when she quit college to become an apprentice chef. She took up a job at the restaurant where her uncle worked, in Tasmania's far south. By the end of the girlfriend #8217;s first apprenticeship year it was clear she #8217;d inherited her uncle #8217;s habit for charring rich cigarettes between hectic services of set six-course meals, enjoying long staff lunches and indulging in countless knock-off beers despite the foreseeable consequences. I was 18 when my girlfriend got me interested in Anthony Bourdain; she had been a vegetarian as a kid, but had since converted to a nose-to-tail style diet - much like her kitchen superiors. It seemed my girlfriend admired Bourdain #8217;s rockstar approach to cooking and eating. I think she liked that he normalised smoking at the table, swearing, sweating and binge-eating. There was also a quirky, Spike Jonze flavour about scenes in Bourdain #8217;s television shows where he would glug snake-blood or bite into the cheek of a half-boiled hog. Like Bourdain, my girlfriend steered away from more conventional dishes, like Meat and Three Veg, and instead opted to incorporate flavours including pig #8217;s trotter, various types of offal and rich bone stock. My girlfriend would pucker her lips at the chance to eat a hot chilli, and her willingness to bite into the unknown reminded me of Bourdain's recollection of tasting an oyster for the first time. In Kitchen Confidential Bourdain claims his inaugural Oyster experience was likely the catalyst for his passion of odd food textures, weird sources of protein and the addictive theatre of eating something that feels alive in his stomach. I would argue the oyster symbolises Bourdain #8217;s compulsion to fetishise and exploit food for its culture and notoriety. It's not that he doesn't value food, or appreciate flavours, but I wonder how much of what he ate he actually enjoyed. After binge-watching Bourdain #8217;s television programs it #8217;s become slightly triggering to recall scenes where his image and reputation leave him red-faced and hiding Portuguese delicacies in a napkin under the table, or watching a goat get slaughtered. There have been times where my girlfriend has taken the same overly-ambitious approach to off-centre culinary experiences, and suffered the digestinal ramifications. Although sometimes Bourdain was rude (particularly towards vegans), I know now that he was his own harshest critic. I #8217;ll kinda miss his sleazy, chicken grease smile and maudlin travel reviews. I had hoped one day I would meet Bourdain and we #8217;d make witty banter about my recent conversion to veganism, and the occasional cock. It seems, however, that he will never meet the two lesbians who would have cooked him dinner and let him fuck them.

I'm a lesbian and I just posted a v relevant fanfic, for your reference. I feel like Tony's wisdom could be subconsciously interpreted as paternal stoicism. Maybe that has something to do with the attraction?? I know he complained a lot but he was a resilient, straight-shooter with a clear ability to empathise.
Thank you! I appreciate it! It's fun to soliloquise online.
Maudlin but not necessarily morose... an ember can reignite but a flame is fleeting. I give it A+, five stars, 10/10!!

Has anyone else stopped cooking because of crying? Television programs focussed on cooking tend to have a cathartic, comforting affect on the viewer. Ironically, I first binge-watched Bourdain's programs after I suffered a death in the family. Now that Bourdain's passed away I can't bring myself to watch his shows because it's too triggering. I worry that this connection between cooking and grief will bury my enthusiasm for eating. I haven't been able to cook a proper meal the last few months...just being in the kitchen emotionally drains me. Pls help. I'm getting kinda hungry.

I like how the poem is super dark but has cute couplets. Do you keep a journal? I feel like you could go a lot deeper if you wanted to. Practicing automatic writing is a good way to get your darkest thoughts on the page. I hope you are doing ok!

WRITING.TITLE: Twentysomething typecasting
WRITING.TEXT: The **Crust Kids** collude with #160; the #160; **Drapes** #160; Only S**quares** talk #160; to #160; **Toffs** The **Gutter Punks** **Scrape** #160; the dumpster #160; A **YoPro** gets #160; the inside story #160; **Cultural Trash** broken into shards parts shine light blinds

Poetic journalling! It's a thing! [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poetic\_journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poetic_journal) Also, I like the lines about how you wear colours but feel dull inside. I deliberately wear pink to spite my cynical character and progressive views on gender conformity. It's amazing how many people will tell me I'm looking well, just because I'm in bright clothes.
I'm sorry to hear that. Hopefully the self-awareness you have shown by making those comments will help you manage your emotions. Keep writing and pls share!

Wow, thanks so much for your well-considered feedback! I totally agree that the formatting is weird. I don't know what I was going for there but it's just what came out. As long as there's some hint at rhythm and meter in what I write I'll pop it in the poetry basket. I hope all those terms are still common vernacular! Where I live, in Tasmania's far south, there's been a reemergence of crust punk culture. It got me thinking about other forgotten youth subcultures.

I think you got it! When I was writing it I was imagining myself walking through a high school cafeteria. As someone who feels like an outsider I take note of the groups I don't feel like I don't belong to. The lack of depth in the piece reflects the superficiality of social categorisation. Thanks for your feedback!

In Tasmania, where I live, abortions are highly inaccessible and the facilities do not exist to undergo gender reassignment surgery. It would be amazing if either of these issues could be addressed by our government. I do not think one should have preference over the other, but only one policy can be passed at a time. I'm not sure where you live but it sounds like things are progressing towards a more equitable society. The Tasmanian health minister recently leaked a female ceo's records to expose them for having a pregnancy termination. Life's gr8 here...

I don't agree with half that statement but you've just indicated that the two issues are quite different. Services for one should not come at the expense of the other. I think it's just a matter of the first serious, long-term studies into the medicine and psychology of gender dysmorphia/ gender reassignment are beginning to emerge and be taken seriously. Governments are responding to that. It's sorta comparable to a 'wave' of feminism. Unfortunately, the rise of the political right (in Australia and the U.S, at least) continues to make it incredibly difficult for any issue regarding the rights of a minority group to progress. Things are still pretty lousy all 'round.

Haha, yeah, our politics are a bit of a joke. Tasmania is an island. Population: 500,000. Our Health Minister is a cis-male hetero jerk who cheats on his wife then goes to church on a Sunday. Basically, the only place offering (relatively) affordable surgical terminations was closed down last year. It's meant some girls have had to fly to mainland Australia for the operation, and that comes at a huge cost (emotionally, physically and professionally). If you go through the public service chances are the doctor will come up with some ridiculous reason why you can't have the procedure. The only other option is to convince a gyno to do it but that costs SO MUCH money. The area where I live (Burnie) is super isolated, has a huge drug problem and more than 7 babies are born each week, despite the population being tiny (20,000). Often, the children in primary school will have better literacy skills than their parents. For trans folk in this community there is (I think) one support service that can put people in touch with open-minded medical professionals. At the moment the Greens political party is calling on the state government to allow people to alter their gender on their birth certificate without having to undergo full gender reassignment surgery first. If someone is interested in pursuing gender reassignment surgery there are people in the Tasmanian Health System who will help, but the process will ultimately involve many trips to see specialists on the mainland. Also, if you happen to be in a heterosexual marriage then you will have to get divorced before you can legally change your gender. This is despite same sex marriage being legal and the state government has been ordered to change that legislation. They have literally said they do not consider it a priority. ANYWAY, here's a link to a song by a Tasmanian band that actually happens to be about getting an abortion. It's called Urine Trouble. Get ittt?? [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cDmE70W7v-s](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cDmE70W7v-s) #8203;

WRITING.TITLE: Am I owed thanks for house-sitting?
WRITING.TEXT: Should I get thanked/rewarded for house-sitting and looking after two dogs for two weeks? I fed the beasts raw chicken carcasses every day and I'm vegan. I was house-sitting for a colleague. I think she thinks she was doing me a favour but I already had a home so there was no gain. I just did it cos she said she had no other options.
The dogs were HUGE (and stinky).
Lack of financial payment doesn't even bother me. Gratitude is priceless!
THANK YOU so much for this validation/ acknowledgement.

WRITING.TITLE: How to handle colleagues with stinky meat-based lunches.
WRITING.TEXT: I've already been told this is a silly thing to complain about but it won't stop bothering me... A fellow I work with eats curried sausages for lunch EVERY DAY and it stinks out the whole office from approx 12.01pm until COB. The smell is so strong it makes me gag. I don't even know what is in that dish but it seems fucking foul. How do my fellow vegans manage the choking scent of reheated meat in the workplace? Is it something I just have to put up with or is there some sort of compromise I reach with my colleagues? Please help. I avoid eating my own lunch because it means going into the kitchen area which stinksss. #8203;
Good idea! I only wish my colleague was the one who would take it outside...
Yay! Glad to know I'm not being totally pedantic.
Omg yes, I'll retaliate with the pungent scent of pine!

LOVE the morose ending. LOVE the sense of nostalgia and the overarching simile. The one thing that kinda irks me is only two lines rhyme, and they don't really flow with the rest of the piece. It's also a bit jarring that some sentences are over two lines, while others three or four. If I read it aloud it's hard to get the rhythm right.

Honestly, you'd be best to catch the bus from Bellerive. There's a pretty regular service from there into Hobart. I think a lot of Eastern Shore folk drive into Bellerive then hop on a bus to get to work.

Head to a place called Waratah. It's sparsely populated so when it snows it's remarkably quiet and pristine. Close to Cradle Mountain so you can go on a day trip there. It's also the site of Tasmania's first tin mine (not that I support mining) and has a nice waterfall. It's summer though so you might have to wait a few months for snow...
Wow! You ACTUALLY changed it and it's ACTUALLY better! Cool! A++

So this is for bisexuals who may not identify as part of the queer community? People who hold traditional views but can't comprehend their own diversion? I'm not sure, sounds a bit like a platform for internalised biphobia but I'll wait and see.

Sometimes I can't tell if I feel like crying, hiding or screaming. It's a weird mix of dread and adrenaline. Feels a bit like I am dying so I try to expel it by crying but nothing comes out. Often leads to a period of sitting in the middle of a room, in a state of catatonia/physical paralysis.
